text: プラグ挿入。全機補助電源にて起動完了。 / 第一ロックボルト外せ。
translation: Plug insertion. All units startup complete on auxiliary power. / Remove first lock bolt.
grammar: にて indicates the means/method; 完了 marks completion; 外せ is the imperative form of 外す

text: 2番から32番までの油圧ロックを解 / 除。 / 圧力ゼロ。状況フリー。
translation: Release hydraulic locks from 2 to 32. / Pressure zero. Status free.
grammar: から...まで indicates range; を marks the direct object

text: カマはん 各機実力で高速部を強制除去 出撃しろ
translation: Kama-han, each unit forcibly remove the high-speed section with physical strength. Launch!
grammar: で indicates means/method; しろ is the imperative form of する

text: 目標は直上にて停止の模様
translation: The target appears to have stopped directly above.
grammar: にて indicates location; の模様 expresses 'appears to be' or 'seems like'

text: 作業!急いで!
translation: Work! Hurry!
grammar: て-form used as imperative for urgency

text: 非常用バッテリー搭載完了! / よし!いけるわ!発進!
translation: Emergency battery installation complete! / Alright! We can do this! Launch!
grammar: いける (potential form of 行く) means 'can go/can do it'

text: もう!かっこ悪い! / 縦穴に出るわよ / うっ!うっ! / うっ!
translation: Geez! This is so uncool! / We're going out through the vertical shaft! / Ugh! Ugh! / Ugh!
grammar: わよ is feminine emphatic ending; に marks destination

text: ああ!またしてもカッコ悪い!
translation: Aah! Once again, so uncool!
grammar: またしても emphasizes repetition

text: いけない!よけて!
translation: Oh no! Dodge!
grammar: て-form used as imperative command

text: このような
translation: Something like this...
grammar: このような is an incomplete utterance expressing surprise or dismay

text: 目標は強力な8日駅で本部に直接進入を図るつもりね / どうすの?決まってんじゃない!やっつけんのよ! / だからどうやってだよ!
translation: The target intends to penetrate directly into headquarters with a powerful acid. / What do we do? Isn't it obvious! We're gonna beat it! / That's why I'm asking how!
grammar: つもり expresses intention; 決まってんじゃない is contraction of 決まっているではない (isn't it decided/obvious)

text: ライフルは落としちゃったし、背中の電池は切れちゃったし / あと3分も動かないよ
translation: We dropped the rifle, and the battery on the back ran out. / We can't move for even 3 more minutes.

vocabulary.meaning: to run out, be used up

grammar: ちゃった is colloquial form of てしまった (regrettable completion); し lists reasons; も emphasizes 'even'

text: 作戦はあるわ / ここに留まる機体がディフェンス / ATフィールドを中和しつつ / 奴の妖怪機からオフェンスを守る / バックアップは加工
translation: I have a plan. / The unit staying here is defense. / While neutralizing the AT Field, / protect offense from its acid. / Backup is Kaoru.
grammar: つつ indicates simultaneous action ('while doing'); から indicates source or origin

text: 落ちたライフルを回収しオフェンスに渡す / そしてオフェンスはライフルの一斉者にて目標を破壊 / これでいいわね
translation: Recover the dropped rifle and pass it to offense. / Then offense destroys the target with concentrated rifle fire. / This is good, right?
grammar: し connects actions; にて indicates means; これでいいわね seeks confirmation with feminine ending

text: いいわディフェンスは私が / お会いにくさま
translation: Fine, I'll be defense. / How unfortunate for you.
grammar: が marks the subject; お会いにくさま is a set phrase expressing mock sympathy

text: 私がやるわ / そんな危ないよ / だからなのよ / あんたにこの前の借りを返しとかないと気持ち悪いからね。
translation: I'll do it. / That's too dangerous! / That's exactly why. / I need to repay my debt to you from before or it'll feel weird.
grammar: とかないと is contraction of ておかないと (if I don't do in advance); から indicates reason

text: シンジがオフェンス、優等生がバックアップ。 / いいわね。 / わかった。
translation: Shinji is offense, honor student is backup. / That's good, right? / Got it.
grammar: が marks subject/agent; いいわね seeks confirmation

text: じゃあ、行くわよ!
translation: Alright, here we go!
grammar: わよ is feminine emphatic ending expressing determination

text: ゲーム!
translation: Game on!
grammar: English loanword used as exclamation

text: アスカ!
translation: Asuka!
grammar: Character name called out in alarm

text: ん? / やっ! / あ!ちょっと! / ちょっと! / あ!
translation: Hm? / Hey! / Ah! Wait! / Wait! / Ah!
grammar: Interjections and exclamations expressing surprise

text: 不潔
translation: Indecent.
grammar: Single word utterance expressing disgust

text: 電気…人工の光がないと、星がこんなにきれいだなんて皮肉なもんだね
translation: Electricity... It's ironic that without artificial light, the stars are this beautiful.
grammar: ないと expresses conditional 'if there isn't'; だなんて emphasizes surprise; もん is colloquial form of もの

text: でも、明かりがないと人が住んでる感じがしないわ
translation: But without light, it doesn't feel like people live here.
grammar: ている indicates ongoing state; 感じがする expresses a feeling or sense; ないと is conditional

text: ほら、こっちの方が落ち着くもの / 人は闇を恐れ、火を使い、闇を削って生きてきたわ / 哲学
translation: See, this way is more calming. / People feared darkness, used fire, and have lived by carving away the darkness. / Philosophy.
grammar: ほら draws attention; 方が indicates comparison; てきた shows continuity from past to present

text: だから人間って特別な生き物なのかな / だから人は攻めてくるのかな
translation: So I wonder if humans are special creatures? / So I wonder if that's why the Angels attack us?
grammar: って is casual topic marker; かな expresses wondering; てくる indicates direction toward speaker

text: あんたバカ?そんなのわかるわけないじゃん
translation: Are you stupid? There's no way to know something like that.
grammar: わけない expresses impossibility; じゃん is casual contraction of じゃない (negative ending with emphasis)

text: 使徒殲滅に己の業をぶつけるミサト / 語られる / 過去 / だが清掃権より飛来する最大の使徒は / 人々に希望を捨てさせた
translation: Misato confronts the Angels with her own karma. / Her past / is revealed. / But the largest Angel flying from outer space / made people abandon hope.
grammar: に marks target; を marks object; させた is causative past (made people do); より indicates source/origin

text: 次回奇跡の価値はみんなで見てね
translation: Next time, 'The Value of a Miracle' - watch it together everyone!
grammar: で indicates means/accompaniment (together); てね is gentle imperative with seeking agreement
